Chapter 31: The Chapter on Happiness
When victorious, enemies are destroyed; when defeated, one feels ashamed of oneself. When at peace, one is happy,
Without the mind of victory or defeat.

When victorious, enemies are destroyed; when defeated, one feels ashamed of oneself means that like those enemies who watch for an opportunity day and night, they have great resentment and dislike towards that person, and from one world to the next they do not abandon their resentment and hatred. In this way, they go through hundreds of thousands of lifetimes, and only when the retribution for their resentment comes to an end do they feel ashamed of their defeat. Therefore it is said, When victorious, enemies are destroyed; when defeated, one feels ashamed of oneself.

When at peace, one is happy, without the mind of victory or defeat means that all afflictions are completely extinguished without remainder, and one does not give rise to thoughts of attachment again. There is also no mind of victory or defeat, thinking I am victorious, they are not or They are victorious, I am not. There is no thought of self and other at all. Therefore it is said, When at peace, one is happy, without the mind of victory or defeat.
If a person disturbs others, seeking peace and happiness for themselves in the world,
They will only create enemies and hatred, and will never escape suffering and affliction.

If a person disturbs others, seeking peace and happiness for themselves in the world, there are many people in the world who hold confused thoughts, harbor deep enmity, disturb others, and hope for their own happiness and the blessings of their clan, like planting bitter seeds and hoping for sweet fruits, wasting their efforts and doing no good for the times.
Therefore it is said, If a person disturbs others, seeking peace and happiness for themselves in the world.

They will only create enemies and hatred, and will never escape suffering and affliction. Even killing someone in a sudden fight can still be forgiven, but harboring poison and plotting in secret is unpardonable. Such people will surely go to a bad realm. The reason is that they hold onto their foolishness and do not let go.
Therefore it is said, They will only create enemies and hatred, and will never escape suffering and affliction.
Those who delight in desires, using sticks to harm living beings,
Seeking one's own comfort in the midst of this, one will not attain happiness in the next world.

Those who delight in love and desire, all sentient beings crave happiness and do not enjoy suffering and distress. Seeing suffering, the minds of the multitude do not wish for happiness. One oneself kills and teaches others to kill, one oneself indulges in lust and teaches others to indulge in lust, one oneself speaks falsely and frivolously and teaches others to speak falsely and frivolously, one oneself takes what is not given and teaches others to steal others' things. Therefore it is said, Those who delight in love and desire.

Using a staff to harm sentient beings, one's actions are unlawful and one oppresses the people. What one intends to do is to harm as the basis. Therefore it is said, Using a staff to harm sentient beings.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

Seeking happiness for oneself in this life, one does not attain happiness in the next world. When people engage in evil conduct, it is all for their own sake. Abandoning the body and receiving a form, they encounter various sufferings, transmigrate through birth and death, and drift in the five destinies. Wherever they are born, their sins and suffering follow them. Therefore it is said, Seeking happiness for oneself in this life, one does not attain happiness in the next world.
If a person wishes to attain joy and happiness, they should not use a staff to harm living beings.
Seeking happiness for oneself in this life, one will also attain happiness in the next world.

If a person wishes to attain joy and happiness, they should not use a staff to harm living beings. All sentient beings crave happiness and dislike suffering. Seeing those who suffer, they give rise to a compassionate mind. With the four universal virtues, they view others as their own children. They never give rise to resentment or beat sentient beings. In the world, they all seek to secure their own bodies.
If I were to harass them today, in the next world I would receive countless retributions.
Therefore it is said, If a person wishes to attain joy and happiness, do not use a stick to harm living beings, seek happiness within, and you will attain happiness in the next world.
Delight in the Dharma and delight in practicing, be careful not to practice evil dharmas,
Those who are able to skillfully practice the Dharma, will have happiness in this world and the next.

When a person is in the world, they should focus on practicing the Dharma, selecting good dharmas and abandoning evil ones, going around and coming back, following good friends and collecting good teachings, wherever they go they should promote Dharma activities. Therefore it is said, Delight in the Dharma and delight in practicing, be careful not to practice evil dharmas, those who are able to skillfully practice the Dharma, will have happiness in this world and the next.
Those who protect the Dharma and practice the Dharma, by practicing the Dharma they obtain good rewards,
This accords with the teachings of the Dharma, by practicing the Dharma one does not go towards evil.

As for those who protect the Dharma and practice the Dharma, those who practice the Dharma and obtain good rewards, they are able to protect themselves and the Dharma, preventing it from leaking out, and later obtain its blessings. Therefore it is said, Those who protect the Dharma and practice the Dharma, those who practice the Dharma and obtain good rewards.

As for this accords with the teachings of the Dharma, practicing the Dharma does not lead to evil, those who practice in accordance with the Dharma protect themselves with the Dharma. In the places where they are born, they do not encounter evil calamities. From small to large, they all receive their retribution. When the blessings received by the gods are exhausted, they are reborn in the human realm and again receive blessings. Therefore it is said, This accords with the teachings of the Dharma, practicing the Dharma does not lead to evil.
As for those who protect the Dharma and practice the Dharma, like a canopy covering their form,
This accords with the teachings of the Dharma, practicing the Dharma does not lead to evil.

Those practitioners who uphold the profound Dharma and the subtle teachings, who remove all hindrances, are like those who, in the scorching heat, obtain a good parasol and are able to cross over. Therefore it is said, Those who uphold the Dharma and practice the Dharma are like a parasol covering their bodies. This accords with the teachings of the Dharma and does not lead to evil.
Evil conduct leads to hell, wherever one falls into evil paths,
Non-Dharma brings about one's own downfall, like grasping a snake with one's hand.

Evil conduct leads to hell, wherever one falls into evil paths. When a person engages in evil conduct, it is not done by parents, siblings, or relatives, but is all due to one's own actions that lead to offenses. One creates the offenses and experiences the calamity oneself, and there is no one who can take one's place.
The views of non-Buddhist teachings and other schools are not the same. The views of non-Buddhists are that one's own body creates offenses while others experience the retribution.
Therefore it is said, Evil conduct leads to hell, wherever one falls into evil paths.

If one violates the Dharma and drowns oneself, it is like grasping a poisonous snake with one's hand. It is like a person who either captures a poisonous snake with a spell, or captures it with medicinal herbs, or plays with an evil snake with his hand according to his teacher's instructions, but after the spell is finished, he is bitten by the snake, dies and enters hell, hungry ghosts, or animals, and goes through birth and death without rest.
Therefore it is said, If one violates the Dharma and drowns oneself, it is like grasping a poisonous snake with one's hand.
Not by Dharma or non-Dharma, the two matters have the same retribution.
Non-Dharma enters hell, the right Dharma is born in the heavens.

Not by Dharma or non-Dharma, the two matters have the same retribution. This kind of sentient being creates good and evil actions, but does not realize the retribution of misfortune and blessings. Those who do good do not know that good has a retribution, and those who do evil do not know that evil has a retribution.
It is like a person who obtains poisoned food, obtains and enjoys it, does not know that there is poison in the food, and the poisonous qi spreads and does not relieve their body.
A person who practices evil is also like this, at that time it is sweet in the mouth but later they receive the calamity, and finally lose their life and do not go to a good place.
A person with eyes observes the food and knows it, this is pure and there is no poison in it, then they take and eat it and later there is no suffering or affliction.
Therefore it is said, Do not use the Dharma and non-Dharma, the two matters have the same retribution, non-Dharma enters hell, and the right Dharma gives rise to heaven.
Giving and fighting are in the same place, this virtue and wisdom are not praised,
When giving and when fighting, this matter is equal in both cases.

In the past, in the city of ÅšrÄvastÄ«, there was an elder named Supreme, and another elder named Invincible, the two of them being the most stingy and greedy in the country, with abundant wealth and treasures, the seven precious things complete, elephants, horses, carriages, servants, slaves, and grain and food fields beyond measure.
The two of them each had seven layers of gates, and ordered the gatekeepers not to let beggars enter their gates.

In the middle of the courtyard, an iron cage was covered above, fearing that flying birds would peck and pick at the grain, and the walls of the house were cast with iron fences, fearing that rats would gnaw through and damage the utensils.

At that time, the five great disciples each went to them in turn to teach and transform them, emerging from the ground and teaching them the Dharma of giving, but the two elders, upon hearing it, each did not accept the teaching.

Later, the Buddha himself went and sat and lay in the sky, emitting a great radiance. The Buddha spoke the subtle Dharma to the elders, but although the elders heard it, their minds still did not understand, and they thought to themselves:
The Buddha has come to our house, we cannot let him return to the monastery empty-handed, we should go into the treasury and take out a white cloth to offer to the TathÄgata.

He got up and went into the treasury to select a bad one, but he got a good one instead, so he discarded it and took another, but he got an even better one, his mind and will argued with each other and he could not decide for himself.
On that day, the asuras were fighting with the TrÄyastriá¹ƒÅ›a Heaven, sometimes the gods won and the asuras lost, sometimes the asuras won and the gods lost.
At that time, the World-Honored One used his heavenly eye to observe the elder's mind, sometimes the stingy mind won and the giving mind lost, sometimes the giving mind won and the stingy mind lost.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke this verse:
Giving and fighting are in the same place, this virtue is not praised by the wise,
When giving and when fighting, these two things are equal.
The elder heard this from afar and felt ashamed in his heart:
The TathÄgata's words are indeed about me.

He then took out fine silk to offer, and the elder Nanda took out five hundred taels of gold to give in charity. With their minds opened and their intentions resolved, they each saw the traces of the path.
When a person encounters a hundred thousand changes, they equally remove the resentment of arrogance,
The pure mind of timely giving, the most excellent of the strong.

When a person encounters a hundred thousand changes, they equally remove the resentment of arrogance means that when a student is at home, they are attached to wealth and affairs, and their mind is not fixed due to the chaos of many things. If a person wishes to cultivate the path, they should leave family affairs and remove arrogance, not giving rise to attachment, and then they can give without expecting reward. Being humble and respectful is the basis for cultivating virtue, while despising others and valuing oneself is a disaster. Therefore, the teaching instructs people to be in a quiet place, and only then can they cultivate the true path.
Therefore, it is said, When a person encounters a hundred thousand changes, they equally remove the resentment of arrogance.

At the time of giving, with a pure mind, the hero is the most excellent one. Giving has five times when one obtains five merits, removing the mind of arrogance and self-importance, the mind is always pure and does not harbor defilement. Therefore it is said, At the time of giving, with a pure mind, the hero is the most excellent one.
Forbearance gains victory over many with little, precepts are superior to the indolent with many.
Those with faith and generosity will receive good rewards in their next life.

Forbearance gains victory over many with little, precepts are superior to the indolent with many. There are many beings with extremely little faith and rampant anger. Those who uphold the precepts and practice forbearance are also few. By being able to practice forbearance, one gains victory over one's enemies. The person who upholds the precepts is superior to the indolent one. It is like Aniruddha who once had the virtue of giving to a pratyekabuddha. For ninety kalpas, he never went to an evil realm, and later was reborn in the ÅšÄkya clan. He was the Buddha's paternal cousin, left home to study the path, and attained the fruit of the path.
Therefore it is said, Forbearance gains victory over much, precepts are superior to much laziness. Those with faith and generosity will receive good rewards in their next life.
Oh, what great blessings and rewards! All wishes are fully accomplished!
Quickly attain the supreme extinction, gradually entering the realm of the unconditioned.

Oh, what great blessings and rewards! All wishes are fully accomplished! The cultivation of blessings by people is all due to the practice established in previous lives. Even if the seeds sown in a good field of blessings are few, the rewards obtained are immeasurable. If one's previous lives offended sages, the mind of giving is not pure and there is no equal intention. Even if one receives a human form, the appearance is ugly and one is despised by others. Doing evil receives evil, doing good receives blessings. Therefore it is said, Oh, what great blessings and rewards! All wishes are fully accomplished!

Quickly attaining the foremost extinction, gradually entering the realm of the unconditioned, means that all bonds are eliminated, all virtues are fully possessed, pure like light, clear and penetrating inside and out. Those who wish to seek the foremost truth will immediately attain it. If one wishes to permanently enter the realm of emptiness, one will immediately attain it without any doubt or obstruction.
Even if the evil demons of external heterodoxies come to destroy those who have accumulated merit, they will immediately be destroyed themselves, and there will be nothing they can do about it.

It is like the ancient Mara who led an army of 18 koá¹­is, with a body of a hundred heads, a terrifying appearance, tigers, wolves, lions, poisonous snakes, and venomous vipers, to frighten the TathÄgata. The TathÄgata's power of merit caused Mara to be destroyed.
Mara retreated, and at that time the World-Honored One then spoke this verse:
Excellent indeed is the great reward of merit, all wishes are fully accomplished,
Quickly attaining the foremost extinction, gradually entering the realm of the unconditioned.
If one seeks skillful means, bestowing the wisdom of the sages,
Exhausting the root of suffering, one should know that one has attained great fortune.

If one seeks skillful means, the wise and holy bestow wisdom. If a learner wishes to practice the holy Dharma, with courageous and diligent effort, without a scattered mind, then one should accord with the Dharma of the sages. Therefore it is said, If one seeks skillful means, the wise and holy bestow wisdom.

As for exhausting the root of suffering, one should know that one has attained great fortune, what is called suffering are the five aggregates. One who can extinguish this accords with the teachings of the Way. Therefore it is said, Exhausting the root of suffering, one should know that one has attained great fortune.
Loving the Dharma, sleeping and waking well, the mind and thoughts are pure and clean,
The Dharma spoken by the sages is enjoyed by the wise.

Learners practice and penetrate the profound Dharma, understand and discern the meaning and phrases, with a tranquil mind without other thoughts, enter concentration with a single intention, not swayed by various delusions, cherish and practice the teachings of the sages and cannot abandon them, what the wise practice is not discussed by the foolish. Therefore it is said, Loving the Dharma, sleeping well, the mind pure and clean, the Dharma taught by the sages, is enjoyed by the wise.
If one's mind delights in meditation, it also delights in non-arising,
It also delights in the four foundations of mindfulness, as well as the seven factors of awakening,
And the four bases of supernatural power, the noble eightfold path.

If one's mind delights in meditation, it also delights in non-arising, the practitioner delights in meditation because he wishes to attain nirvana in the realm of no remainder, without arising or ceasing. Therefore it is said, If one's mind delights in meditation, it also delights in non-arising.

Also delighting in the four foundations of mindfulness and the seven factors of awakening, means to stop the arising of afflictions and be mindful, and to be enlightened, which is called the factors of awakening. Therefore it is said, Also delighting in the four foundations of mindfulness and the seven factors of awakening.

And the four bases of supernatural power, and the noble eightfold path, means that the bases of supernatural power also sever afflictions and bring happiness and non-action in the present Dharma. The noble eightfold path also severs afflictions in the present Dharma and brings happiness and good benefits. Therefore it is said, And the four bases of supernatural power, and the noble eightfold path.
Delight in solid food, delight in the Dharma robes,
Delight in walking meditation, delight in dwelling in the mountains and forests.

They delight in alms-food and delight in wearing the Dharma robes means that the practitioner, having attained the wisdom of cutting off all [afflictions], distinguishes the notion of food and is not attached to it. Whether the food is good or bad, the mind is without approval or disapproval. The Dharma robes are neat and do not violate the attire of the sages of the past. Therefore, it is said, They delight in alms-food and delight in wearing the Dharma robes.
They delight in walking meditation and delight in dwelling in the mountains and forests means as it is said in the Buddha's sutras, those who practice walking meditation attain five merits.
What are the five?

First, they are able to travel far; second, they have much strength; third, whatever they eat and drink is naturally digested; fourth, they are free from illness; fifth, those who practice walking meditation quickly attain meditative concentration.

Those who practice the Way attain the subtle Dharma of the Four Noble Truths as they truly are. Hearing the Dharma, their minds awaken, and they immediately enter the deep mountains, a place without people, to practice meditation and the Way, and attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the realm of nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder.
Therefore it is said, They delight in walking meditation, and delight in the mountains and forests.
Attaining a state of bliss, they are unconditioned in the present Dharma,
Surpassing all fears, they transcend the world's defilements and attachments.

Attaining a state of bliss, they are unconditioned in the present Dharma means that like those practitioners, in the realm of nirvÄá¹‡a with remainder they enjoy the true Dharma for themselves, gradually progressing until they attain nirvÄá¹‡a in the realm of complete cessation. Therefore it is said, Attaining a state of bliss, they are unconditioned in the present Dharma.

Transcending all fears and going beyond worldly defilements, by seeing the path one transcends all suffering and difficulty, going beyond worldly defilements and practices that transcend the three realms, becoming a field of merit for the multitude. Therefore it is said, Transcending all fears and going beyond worldly defilements.
Good is the delight in mindfulness, good is the contemplation of all dharmas,
Excellent is the world without harm, nurturing the various kinds of beings.
In the world without desire and delight, transcending defiled thoughts,
Able to extinguish one's own arrogance, this is called the highest bliss.

The TathÄgata descended and came to the king's house, contemplating that the world is impermanent and all things are like illusions. He abandoned the king's position and studied the Way in the deep mountains for many years of ascetic practice. Sitting under the king of trees, he attained perfect supreme enlightenment. For seven days and nights he contemplated the tree without blinking.
At that time, the TathÄgata immediately rose from his seat and went to the palace of the nÄga king Muchilinda, and spoke this verse:
The dragon heard this verse and his mind opened up, his eyes opened, and he saw the TathÄgata's form. He was moved to tears and reproached himself for his past offenses.
Therefore it is said:
Good to delight in mindfulness, good to contemplate all dharmas,
Excellent in the world without harm, nurturing all kinds of beings.
In the world without the pleasure of desire, transcending all defiled intentions,
Able to extinguish one's own arrogance, this is called the highest pleasure.
The pleasure of the elderly upholding precepts, the pleasure of having faith and accomplishment,
The pleasure of discerning meanings and principles, the pleasure of not creating various evils.

As for the pleasure of the elderly upholding precepts, although a person who studies the Way may be old and feeble, they do not complain of hardship. There is a mind of retreat. Although they may be young and see worldly glory, they are still lazy. The Way lies in the mind, not asking about old or young, only in being resolute and reaching the Way. As long as one's faith remains, wherever one goes, one will succeed.
Therefore it is said, The joy of the aged is in observing the precepts.

As for those with accomplished faith, it is difficult for them to be moved by the four things. Even if transformed into the form of a Buddha, displaying various radiant appearances, those who come to deceive them cannot cause their minds to waver. Therefore it is said, Those with accomplished faith are joyful.

As for discerning the meaning, a person's eloquence is all due to past practices. After millions and billions of kalpas, they attain eloquence. Although they speak and teach, discerning various meanings, each and every direction does not lose its sequence. From a single meaning, they expound up to a hundred thousand, never uttering coarse words. Therefore it is said, Discerning the meaning is joyful.
As for not creating various evils, if a person has no evil, they will be born in the heavens and among humans to receive blessings. Therefore it is said, The joy of not creating various evils.
The joy of having parents in the world, the joy of the harmony of the assembly,
There is the joy of Å›ramaá¹‡as in the world, and the joy of those who delight in tranquility is also like this.

There is the joy of parents in the world, and the joy of harmonious assemblies. As the Buddha's sÅ«tras say, the kindness of parents is weighty and cannot be fully described. If filial children wish to repay their kindness, carrying their father on the right shoulder and their mother on the left shoulder, going around the world from birth to old age for hundreds of thousands of eons, they still cannot repay the kindness of their parents for a single day.
Why is this?

It is all because parents nurture the five aggregates and expand the six faculties, enabling them to see light, pushing away dryness and staying in dampness, attending to them according to the seasons.
Therefore, even if filial children wish to repay their kindness, they have not yet attained even a hundredth of it.
Thus it is said, there is the joy of parents in the world, and the joy of harmonious assemblies.

There are Å›ramaá¹‡as in the world who delight in tranquility, and their aspirations for happiness are also thus. They leave home to study the path, severing all affection and love, abandoning worldly affairs, always practicing the three activities without losing their principles. Moreover, they are loved and cherished by hundreds of thousands of beings, who make offerings and provide for their needs according to the season. Renunciant brahmins diligently strive to sever bonds and attachments, practicing pure conduct and not creating evil roots. Therefore it is said, 'There are Å›ramaá¹‡as in the world who delight in tranquility, and their aspirations for happiness are also thus.'ğŸ”½The joy of the appearance of buddhas,
the joy of expounding the Dharma and being able to receive it,ğŸ”½the joy of the harmony of the saá¹…gha,
harmony always brings peace.
The joy of the appearance of buddhas means that the appearance of the TathÄgata is extremely rare, like the udumbara flower that appears only once in many thousands of koá¹­Ä«s of kalpas.
At that time, when the beings saw the udumbara flower, they each rejoiced and said to each other:
The TathÄgata's appearance in the world will not be long. This auspicious sign must not be false!
Ancient scriptures have their own established texts, if these flowers appear in the world, then the TathÄgata's appearance in the world is also not far off.
The devas and humans of the world rejoice together, all setting up offerings, eagerly awaiting to see the TathÄgata's radiant appearance.
Therefore it is said, The joy of the Buddhas' appearance in the world.

The joy of being able to receive the teaching of the Dharma, when the Buddha first attained the Way and was fully endowed with the marks, for forty-nine days he silently entered concentration, not expounding the flavor of the Dharma to sentient beings. Later, at the request of BrahmÄ Heaven, he gave teachings to the fourfold assembly of monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen, as well as devas, nÄgas, gandharvas, asuras, kiá¹ƒnaras, mahoragas, humans, and non-humans, expounding the good Dharma, and all beings were benefited and saved.
Therefore it is said, The joy of being able to receive the teaching of the Dharma.

The harmony of the Saá¹…gha is also happiness. Harmony means there is always peace. The Saá¹…gha is not a single matter, but may be four, eight, or countless. The TathÄgata's Saá¹…gha is the foremost.

Within the TathÄgata's Saá¹…gha, there are four pairs, eight groups, and twelve noble ones. All sentient beings compete to come and make offerings. Those who respectfully serve the noble Saá¹…gha gain immeasurable blessings.

Such a field of merit gives rise to the fruits of the path. It is good and beautiful, without drought or frost. According to one's wishes, nothing is not accomplished. What the noble Saá¹…gha values is only harmony as supreme. Therefore it is said, The harmony of the Saá¹…gha is also happiness. Harmony means there is always peace.
Happiness in upholding the precepts completely, happiness in being widely learned and knowledgeable,
Happiness in seeing true people, happiness in practicing the traces of liberation.

The joy of perfect observance of precepts means that when sentient beings encounter those who observe the precepts and serve and make offerings to them, looking after them in a timely manner, they will later receive their rewards, peacefully abiding in the unconditioned bliss of freedom. Therefore, it is said, The joy of perfect observance of precepts.

The joy of extensive learning and knowledge means that there are sentient beings who encounter those of extensive learning and accept their teachings, not losing the body of names, the body of phrases, and the body of flavors, with a thorough understanding of the meaning and principles, investigating and penetrating the meaning, hearing and immediately awakening without having to receive them again. Therefore, it is said, The joy of extensive learning and knowledge.

The joy of seeing true persons and the joy of the practice of liberation means that if there are sentient beings with the roots of virtue planted in the past, they will encounter sages and meet those who have attained arhatship, the attainment of the cessation of conceptualization and the attainment of emptiness and tranquility.

There are sentient beings who make offerings to true persons and receive the rewards in their present lives, with wealth and treasures accumulating and their wishes fulfilled without fail. They are forever unstained by the fetters and afflictions.
Therefore it is said, Seeing the true person is joyful, and the practice of liberation is joyful.
The joy of the clear and cool swift water, the delight of gathering the wealth of Dharma by oneself,
The delight of attaining the wisdom and insight of knowledge, the joy of extinguishing arrogance and evil.

The joy of the clear and cool swift water is like a swift river that is calm, clear, and cool, with a subtle and gentle sound that does not harm beings, and is extremely sweet and delicious. Learners crave it and accomplish much. Therefore it is said, The joy of the clear and cool swift water.

The delight of gathering the wealth of Dharma by oneself refers to the wealth of Dharma, which is gathered through the Dharma without oppressing the principles of nature, and is not harmed by county officials, thieves, water, fire, or disasters.
Why is this?
It is all due to the right Dharma that one obtains wealth and profit, and does not oppress people, causing it to be so.
Therefore it is said, The delight of gathering the wealth of Dharma by oneself.

Attaining the bright wisdom of knowledge means that like a learner attaining the foremost wisdom of the world, one is able to discern all dharmas, universally emitting light to awaken others. Therefore it is said, attaining the bright wisdom of knowledge.

Destroying arrogance and evil means that one who harbors arrogance will certainly despise others. From beginningless eons, harboring good virtue without finality is all due to giving rise to anger. Therefore it is said, destroying arrogance and evil.
Seeing the virtuous is joyful, being together with them is also joyful,
Not associating with the foolish, ending the past is forever joyful.

It is joyful to see the virtuous and to be together with them. The sages and saints are endowed with the fruits of the path and possess all virtues. They have cultivated and accumulated practices in the past and have attained them. Those who respectfully serve the virtuous will later receive their joy and have countless wealth and affairs. The family members are harmonious and the clan prospers day by day. Therefore, it is said, It is joyful to see the virtuous and to be together with them.

Do not associate with fools, and in the end, there will be lasting joy. Good people cultivate virtue and seek good companions. Seeing bad acquaintances, they will ultimately stay far away. The reason for this is that bad people ultimately have no good conduct. They fall into darkness and do not see the great light. Therefore, it is said, Do not associate with fools, and in the end, there will be lasting joy.
If one associates with fools, one goes through countless days.
It is difficult to live with fools, like being with enemies and those one dislikes.

It is like working with a fool for countless days. If a practitioner works with a fool, day and night they fall into birth and death, and countless Buddhas have passed by without being able to save them. Therefore it is said, It is like working with a fool for countless days.

Dwelling with fools is difficult, like being with enemies. The suffering of being with enemies is all due to ignorance. One does not follow good teachers or work with wise and virtuous friends. Therefore it is said, Dwelling with fools is difficult, like being with enemies.

Dwelling with the wise is easy, like being with close relatives. What the wise study must be of the highest quality. When they meet, they rejoice together, first smiling and then speaking, with a pleasant and cheerful countenance. Internally and externally they are peaceful and at ease, without any disputes. Therefore it is said, Dwelling with the wise is easy, like being with close relatives.
It is extremely difficult to encounter a human birth, which should never be wasted.
If one is to be reborn, that family will surely be blessed.

The Honored One among Humans is extremely difficult to encounter, and one will never be reborn in vain. For millions and millions of eons, one cannot encounter him. The so-called Honored One among Humans is the World-Honored Buddhas. The so-called place of birth is where the lineage is pure, the parents are genuine, the family is wealthy with abundant treasures, possessing the seven precious things such as gold, silver, agate, pearls, tiger-patterned amber, elephants, horses, and carriages, without any lack or shortage. The country where one is born is harmonious above and below, and everyone follows each other.
Therefore it is said, The Honored One among Humans is extremely difficult to encounter, and one will never be reborn in vain.

If one is to be reborn, that family will surely be blessed. The retinue is accomplished, dwelling in the central country and not in the heretical regions. Therefore it is said, If one is to be reborn, that family will surely be blessed.
All attain good sleep, the brahmin attains nirvana,
Not tainted by desire, completely liberated from all places.

Be careful not to be attached to pleasure, you should follow the practice of protection,
One should remember to let go of the world and contemplate pleasant things.

Be careful not to be attached to pleasure, and should protect the practice that comes. When a person studies the Way, if it is not difficult, it will not be accomplished. It is necessary to be difficult and then it will be accomplished. Let go of worldly meditation and worldly liberation, and cultivate undefiled meditation and undefiled liberation. Therefore it is said, Be careful not to be attached to pleasure, and should protect the practice that comes.

One should remember to let go of the world and contemplate pleasant things means that when a person encounters slight pleasure, they should seek more and increase the basis of their pleasure. Therefore it is said, One should remember to let go of the world and contemplate pleasant things.
Like worldly joy and heavenly bliss,

This is called the end of desire, not even a sixteenth part has been obtained.ğŸ”½Herein, the wise one should contemplate the impermanence of the world, and the mind will be liberated from all suffering.

As for the worldly joy and the joy of the heavens, the worldly joy is the joy of the desire realm, and the heavenly joy is the joy of the form realm. For a long time, sentient beings are deluded in the five destinies and do not know how to rely on the truth. They crave the rewards of worldly meditation and blessings, transmigrating through the five destinies in a cycle. They think that by attaining the Way, they will be eternally extinguished and will not arise again. Therefore, it is said, As for the worldly joy and the joy of the heavens.

As for this being called the end of craving, not obtaining one out of sixteen, there are practitioners who first cut off the root of craving and forever remove the branches and leaves. They hold the intention of fear and prevent evil from happening before it does. Later, they attain the joy of the undefiled and their minds roam freely. Out of the sixteen parts, they have not obtained even one.
Therefore, it is said, This is called the end of craving, not obtaining one out of sixteen.
Able to put down the heavy burden, not creating the heavy burden again,
The suffering of the heavy burden in the world, being able to abandon it is the greatest happiness.

Those who can abandon the heavy burden and do not create another heavy burden, are like a person carrying a heavy burden through a dangerous place. What they are carrying is not something that is not needed by the world or not urgent, nor is it gold, silver, precious treasures, agate, lapis lazuli, pearls, or amber, but rather goods that are not needed by the world. A bystander advises them:
Observe what you are carrying, it is not a true treasure, why don't you abandon it and seek a true one instead?
The person then abandons it and seeks a true one.
Observe that these sentient beings are also like this. Carrying the body of the five aggregates, they wander in the desire realm, rolling in birth and death and unable to escape.
The sages say:
The form of the five aggregates that you are now carrying is filthy, leaking, and foul-smelling. Carrying this is a mistake.
You should quickly abandon it and seek a lighter one.
At that time, sentient beings then devised skillful means, abandoning the form of the desire realm and taking on the body of the form realm.

Having already taken on the form of the form realm, the sages went to them again to teach and transform them, causing them to abandon the body and turn to the five-part Dharma nature of uncontaminated wisdom.
Therefore it is said, Able to abandon the heavy burden, not creating the heavy burden again, the heavy burden is the suffering of the world, able to abandon it is the greatest happiness.
Completely cutting off all desires and attachments, and extinguishing all conditioned activities,
And extinguishing the basis of the five aggregates, no longer accepting the three realms of existence.

Like a practitioner observing with uncontaminated wisdom, extinguishing desires, attachments to form, and attachments to the formless realm, bodily actions, verbal actions, and mental actions, eliminating the three bodily, four verbal, and three mental [misdeeds] forever, completely without remainder, understanding the origin and end of the five aggregates, no longer becoming attached to the activities of the three realms of existence.

Therefore it is said, Completely cutting off all desires and attachments, and extinguishing all conditioned activities, and extinguishing the basis of the five aggregates, no longer accepting the three realms of existence.
When righteousness flourishes, there is joy, friends enjoy the happiness of blessings,
That cessation is tranquil joy, spreading to all people,
Suffering is the basis for happiness.

When righteousness flourishes, there is joy, friends enjoy the happiness of blessings means that just as merchants exhaust their bodies and endure hardships, braving danger and hardship to gather great treasures, returning home safely with their clans rejoicing, with their sons, daughters, and all the family members delighted, and their friends and companions all receiving grace;
If they open their minds and give generously to all, without further suffering, happiness is the basis. The clan's entertainment cannot be separated from this.

Therefore it is said, When righteousness flourishes, there is joy, friends enjoy the happiness of blessings. That cessation is tranquil joy, spreading to all people, suffering is the basis for happiness.
Just like that fire pit, blazing and burning, gradually extinguishing,
Not knowing where it has gone.
Those who see in this way are free from the mud of desire and love,
And even when gone, there is no place, for they attain immovable bliss.

Just like a brazier, with blazing flames, like a smith burning iron balls, extremely blazing and very difficult to approach, so the sages observe that sentient beings are burned by the fire of lust, anger, and delusion, yet they are unaware.
Therefore it is said, Just like a brazier, with blazing flames.

Gradually returning to extinction, not knowing where it goes, like that heated iron ball gradually reaching coolness, not knowing where the heat went, and also not knowing where the coolness is, therefore it is said, Gradually returning to extinction, not knowing where it goes.

Those who have such views are able to escape the mud of desire. The practitioner attains such liberation without obstruction, escapes the deep mud of desire, and is able to leave the shore of birth and death. Therefore it is said, Those who have such views are able to escape the mud of desire.

Going also has no location, attaining immovable bliss. Such beings' spirits merge with the dark, and their consciousnesses and empty bodies also do not know the four directions and above and below. Coming, they do not know where they come from, and going, they do not know where they go. It is like a red-hot iron ball gradually cooling down, not knowing where the heat comes from, and also not knowing where the coolness is. Therefore it is said, Going also has no location, attaining immovable bliss.
In the middle, there is no anger, there is change and instability,
Eliminating worries, there is no sorrow, peacefully observing the existence of the world.

There is no anger in the middle means that anger is a defiled state of mind that does not lead to the Way. Only those without defilements can avoid the mind of anger, therefore it is said there is no anger in the middle.

There are changes and impermanence means that in the world there are many practices, with varying degrees of heaviness and different ways of conduct. Some have a tacit understanding and reach without creating afflictions, while some knowingly commit offenses and give rise to defilements.

Therefore, the sages set forth admonitions for later generations, wanting those who practice to change their past mistakes and cut off future calamities. Those who greedily study cherish and treasure them, and before they fall into the mind they can advance to the abode of sages. Only then do they know that the sage's teachings are to be revered and defiled teachings are not to be approached.
Therefore it is said there are changes and impermanence.

As for removing worries and having no sorrow, it is like a practitioner who forever uproots the roots of worry and sorrow, and accords with the faculty of joy. Tranquil, they observe the changes in the world, like a mirage in the wilderness.
Therefore it is said, Removing worries and having no sorrow, tranquil, observing the existence of the world.

As for having joy and having no affliction, greatly hearing the true Dharma, it is like that person who enters concentration, day and night in meditation tranquility, not apart from the concentrated mind, emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness as their enjoyment. At that time, although the body may undergo suffering practices, the spirit is tranquil and inactive, without any harm or loss. Like that practitioner who has no mind of anger, with compassion and pity for all beings, no different from oneself. Therefore it is said, Having joy and having no affliction, greatly hearing the true Dharma.
As for if one sees there is loss, person after person covets form,

If one sees that there is harm, everyone is greedy for form. Like a practitioner observing the source of the faculties, lust, anger, and ignorance are the root of all calamities. They all arise from the mind of desire and anger, and together they defile and create great suffering, thus one is unable to escape the root of birth, old age, sickness, death, sorrow, and distress.
Therefore it is said, If one sees that there is harm, everyone is greedy for form.
Without knots, worldly goodness and longevity, the great Dharma knows the root of knots,
People should be clear about the flaws of knots, the human mind is bound and attached,
It is also bound to the root of form.

For one without afflictions, lust, anger, and ignorance are exhausted. One no longer delights in the multitude of worldly afflictions, and the root of resentment and enmity does not arise again. The wise person can discern and cut off these afflictions. Having eliminated one's own afflictions, one also treats others to eliminate their afflictions. One also does not think of being attached to various forms. One's mind is unmoved by gain, loss, slander, or praise. Therefore it is said, The world's good life without afflictions, the great Dharma knows the origin of afflictions. People should be clear about the flaws of afflictions. Each person is greedy and attached, and is also bound by the root of form.
All humiliation is suffering, all indulgence is happiness.
Victory and defeat naturally arise, but in the end, nothing is gained.

All suffering from being humiliated, all happiness from being self-indulgent, when a person encounters difficulties and hardships, their mind cannot be at ease, they always look at others' faces, fearing they will offend them. For the self-indulgent person, whatever they desire comes to them as they think, like an echo responding to a sound. Therefore it is said, All suffering from being humiliated, all happiness from being self-indulgent.

Victory and defeat naturally arise, yet in the end there is nothing gained, just as in the world, nobility and humbleness are impermanent, one may be a wheel-turning sage king, and later become a minor king, sometimes noble and sometimes humble, sometimes high and sometimes low. Only the path of sages is without nobility or humbleness, high or low. Therefore it is said, Victory and defeat naturally arise, yet in the end there is nothing gained.
Those who wish for a happy life, can endure the light retribution of others,
The patient one endures the person, the impatient one endures all existences.

To put it briefly, the meaning is this: to give rise to harm where there is no harm, to give rise to trouble where there is no trouble, to give rise to anger where there is no anger, to give rise to enmity where there is no enmity, as above, no different.

Whether in villages or wilderness, seeing suffering or joy, one is not burned by either. When people cultivate the Way, they may live by the city or rely on villages, or in the vast wilderness without people. Sometimes encountering suffering, many people feel pain in their hearts, and when they occasionally experience joy, they do not rejoice in it. They give rise to twelve kinds of illnesses.
That refers to the six sense objects, and this refers to the six sense faculties.
Therefore it is said, Whether in villages or wilderness, seeing suffering or joy, one is not burned by either.

Even if one encounters the traces of suffering and joy, without traces, how can there be suffering? When people are in the world, their minds are always indulgent, first suffering and then joyful, thus increasing the roots of offenses. Sometimes giving rise to suffering and joy in hell, without suffering there are no traces, and there is also no suffering and joy in hell. Therefore it is said, Even if one encounters the traces of suffering and joy, without traces, how can there be suffering?

Wherever there are sages, they are not attached to the defilements of desire. Sages who dwell in the world often conceal themselves, not attached to thoughts of desire and not giving rise to the defilements of desire. These are called sages, the non-returners and arhats.
Therefore it is said, Wherever there are sages, they are not attached to the defilements of desire.
